Wow, I'm kind of impressed that this passed tests. Nice.

Well, the exception `java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: Could not initialize class org.apache.beam.sdk.options.PipelineOptionsFactory
` is caused by enabling `flink-runner` and `gearpump-runner` profiles simultaneously.

:-( OK let us skip enabling the WordCount presubmit. We really should not be enabling all runners at once - the whole point of the profiles is that they will conflict. Hopefully the new pipelined Jenkins config makes this better.
Gonna take a  look.
If Flink users choose a Scala version first and then a corresponding Flink version, I would very much like to support the Beam FlinkRunner working simply for these users. How is this done for Flink?

@kennknowles now that PR https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/3286 is merged, do you think it's useful to add tests for each public method `WindowFnTestUtils.*WithValue` that use the `CustomWindow` (https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/master/sdks/java/core/src/test/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/transforms/windowing/WindowTest.java#L629) to rely on element values ?
Okay, skipped for now. I will try enabling it once the new Jenkins config is in.

This pull request introduces docker images mostly for development purposes (to
have a ready to test environment with the Beam source code), it is like a poor man jenkins but this images can neatly be run in a cluster manager like kubernetes to invoke a maven verification script. I end up coding this to validate the release and reproduce bugs e.g. in JDK 7.

Additionally the PR introduces a docker image to have an out of the box distribution with the python SDK that can submit pipelines to Dataflow. We can in the future publish this one into docker hub if there is interest.

R: @jasonkuster @davorbonaci 
R: @aaltay for the python bits
R: @jbonofre

This is a really simple one I found while validating the Java 9 compile.
R: @aviemzur
retest this please.

Retest this please

With Flink you have to use the right dependencies for your Scala version, i.e. with Scala 2.10 you would have `flink-streaming-java_2.10` and with Scala 2.11 you would have `flink-streaming-java_2.11`. It is very unfortunate that our Scala dependency is shining through here and at some point we might be able to resolve that. But not now.
R: @jbonofre
Maybe it could make sense to have different Dockerfile providing Beam + [Flink/Spark] + [Some "default" IOs] ?
I think it's also related to https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-320: the dockerfiles could package existing Beam distros.

Yes @jbonofre the last docker image (the python one) is definitely closer to BEAM-320, and we can eventually make it part of it because it could be clearly be an out of the box 'binary' distribution of Beam. Or at least a template for devs to use.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/12576000/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/12576000)

Coverage increased (+0.007%) to 70.481% when pulling **86e335595f1274248835e5715229bc67d4233fb3 on iemejia:BEAM-1984-enable-dep-analysis-for-tests** into **e206b1a41c1f22330cb78fd1082425ea1e74dbb4 on apache:master**.

I think we mostly agree on the review with the exception of the slf4j deps, if you want I can revert those and re do the PR. I did this changes because I considered that restricting the dependencies to the minimum scope is a good practice even if in this particular case is not that critical.

Actually, I think we can change a bit this PR to add logging in the IOs. The purpose of having slf4j-api dependency with compile code is because the IOs SHOULD log messages (at least DEBUG) in some methods. More than changing the scope, I would add DEBUG messages in the concerned IOs.
Adding extra logging for the IOs clearly goes beyond the scope of this PR (whose goal is to fix the scope for dependencies needed only for test purposes) so I wouldn't mix both.
In that case, I will focus this PR on joda-time remove, keep sl4j-api dependency as it is and open another PR to add logging messages.

Or, we can also do:
- keep this PR as it is, and then create another PR for logging messages + changing again the slf4j-api dependency scope

Thought ?
Good idea!, it is a good compromise because like this we will fix here the scope and we will redefined when needed, as the logging on the IOs evolve. Like this we can also do this step by step
Fair enough.
Thanks JB !
By the way, I created BEAM-2688 to add the logging messages in the  IOs.

What I see as an open question is how releases would work. We use `maven-release-plugin` which does the publishing to maven, creating the release tag and updating the branch. If we want to release for several Scala versions we would have to do this several times, maybe? But only for the publishing-maven-artifacts part.
We can only remove ``:class:`` from parameter types, return types, and exceptions raised. The rest still have to be kept.

R: @jbonofre
Agree for the itests for both user authentication and SSL mutual authentication. It just means that the elasticsearch instance has to use shield for the itests.

Another comment: 
If the user provides a certificate in his keystore, is the `HttpAsynClient` going to do mutual client + server authentication?
If there is no client certificate in the keystore is it going to be server only SSL authentication?

It depends of the shield configuration:
1. if mutual authentication is needed on the ES side, then,  the client/IO has to  provide a client certificate. The client certificate has to be present and trusted in the server/ES trustsore.
2. if mutual  authentication is not enabled, then, the client/IO can provide or not the client certificate.

What do you mean by server authentication ? Username/password ?

Coverage decreased (-0.02%) to 70.404% when pulling **5ade8d6508d322287f8a24e9d9016bf9bea5725b on pabloem:improv-si** into **7ab8954b9f9fc835750172163a01bdc05d6dfa04 on apache:master**.

Create.ofProvider test is failing because https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/1796 sets a specific version of Jackson. Jackson is used only in SparkRuntimeContext, to serialize and deserialize PipelineOptions. I don't think either of this is correct (we should use just one version of this library, and SparkRuntimeContext shouldn't do its own serialization/deserialization - that's responsibility of something like PipelineOptionsFactory); fixing.

@jkff Just as a comment, the tests are below 20s and I think this 20s for tests should be relaxed for embedded implementations of some of the Apache data stores who depend of multiple infrastructure mechanisms, e.g. this one requires of starting a zookeeper and the hadoop ones are even worse because they require not only a zookeepr but a mini dfs cluster so these things take time, it is normally not an issue of the IO. I think it is way better to have a test with an embedded implementation than a fake even at the cost of some extra seconds.
Yeah, I mean more like "If it's above 20s let's see if we can make it faster" rather than a blanket ban on tests longer than that :)

Astrologers proclaim the week of the nerd-snipe.

I started by fixing SparkRuntimeContext and then noticed that we have 2 more almost identical classes in Flink and Apex, so I instead created a class in runners-core and deduplicated, and deleted SparkRuntimeContext altogether (along with deleting some other dead code hanging onto it). It also turned out that SparkRuntimeContext didn't call FileSystems.setDefaultPipelineOptions - bug averted, I guess.
Run Spark ValidatesRunner
